126131: Festering March.author: Lateralis0ne

Throw in Paradox Haze and Copy Enchantment. With the right deck, this card can pop nearly three times a turn. A good friend of mine ran this card with the other recursion-suspend cards of its cycle, with the Hazes and Copy Enchants, and a couple other cards that capitalize on multiple upkeeps. The win condition cost like 10 USD to put together, and the who engine was run on 700 USD of basic lands. Go figure.

It's incredibly fun to play both with and against, though. I enjoy losing to this deck when I do.

The opponent has had plenty of time to get out several creatures with more than one toughness, and they're the ones you'll be wanting dead. Even against token strategies, the expensive mana cost of this card allows them time to find and cast a tribal lord or other buffing effect. It may re-cast itself later on, but it seems it would be ever less relevant the longer the game lasts.

126132: Edge of Autumn.author: HotHit
126132: Edge of Autumn.text_parsed:
When I first started to play Magic, I thought this card was kinda bad. If you draw it after turn 4 (or earlier considering you're a ramp deck) then you have a card that doesn't do anything in your hand. Making it a lot more situational that rampant growth.

Now that I've played a lot longer, I can see the potential in the cycling effect alone. It's not a rampant growth with downside, but an apology for the downside. It's a unique combo piece that can act as a rampant growth should you need it. It's a keeper in my Jarad EDH deck and definitely worth using in my land casual deck.

Plus it's one of the only autumn themed cards and I loved it for that when I first discovered magic.

126134: Shimian Specter.author: zk3
126134: Shimian Specter.text_parsed:
The speed difference between a 3-CMC and 4-CMC spell is huge. Firstly, a 3-CMC spell fits perfectly in first-turn Dark Ritual for black decks or second turn green spell after first-turn llanowar elves. Mana ramping is most efficient in the first two turns, and therefore the gap between the level of your vs. your opponent's spells is the most significant. Increasing the cost by one mana means delaying one whole turn until it can be played - in which case most competitive decks would have evolved the board positions by then.
As such, some of the best 4-CMC cards are able to offer much better effects than their 3-CMC counterparts. Shimian Specter is an excellent example of the benefits gained at the price of tempo.

Because of its lack of speed, this card can't ever be a game-breaker or carry a strategy on its back as Hypnotic Specter could, but definitely a solid supporting member.

126141: Cryptic Annelid.author: igniteice
126141: Cryptic Annelid.text_parsed:
Look at the first card. Want to keep it on top? Put it on top of library. Look at the second two cards. You already know you're keeping one of them, so you're really only looking at 1 more card. Put it on top and your next scry only lets you see one last card, effectively making this a scry 3. Put the second card on the bottom though and you'll see two additional cards.

So then this becomes the problem: for four mana, you're getting either: look at the top three cards of your library and put them back in any order, or put the top six cards of your library on the bottom, with variations in between. Unfortunately, those variations are directly influenced by previous choices, with each card being kept on top making the next scry less effective. For instance, the only way to look at six cards is to put the cards from the first two scrys on the bottom. If you keep even one card from either the first or second scry, you'll only be able to dig a maximum of four cards deep.

There are four practical ways to look at 6 total cards, three to look at 5 cards, five to look at 4 cards, and two to look at 3 cards. To look at six different cards you need to put the first three cards you see from the first two cards on the bottom. Now you have 3 new cards to scry.

To look at five cards, you need to put the first card on the bottom, then keep only one of the second scry. This of course means that you'll only be seeing two new cards in the third scry, because one of them you saw in the second scry. So effectively you saw three cards: you put two on the bottom, kept one, and now you have two more to look at.

To look at only four cards, you can keep the first card and keep one card of the second scrys, or put the first card on the bottom and keep both cards from the second scry. Either one of these options will cause you to see only four different cards.

If you choose to keep both the first card and the second different card from the second scry, you'll only see 3 different cards.

126148: Putrid Cyclops.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
126148: Putrid Cyclops.text_parsed:
Scry in with a (very good) possibility for a decent body with a relevant creature type.

In a Modern zombie deck, wouldn't you want to have Bob and a low curve? This'll let you scry and see the next card to plan for the Confidant upkeep trigger. If you have a Zombie lord on the field and your curve tops out at three, you're guaranteed to never lose the Putrid Cyclops. And it's not like your opponent will be surprised to see your deck has zombies and swamps. (Caveat: I've never actually played with a Dark Confidant, so this is just speculation. I'm starting to play Modern at the FNM level, but I'm not keen on dropping $75 for a single card just yet.)

This seems far more interesting than Warpath Ghoul and superior to it in some decks. It's a fun Johnny card.

@TheWrathOfShane: You posted too early. After Born of the Gods, you could've said, "Dies to Eye Gouge." : )

@wholelottalove: It's not a Legacy card. It was first printed in Time Spiral.

@kajillion: You think "better" and "higher-mana-cost" are synonyms? There are many times even late in a game you will be better off drawing a Doom Blade or the last Swamp you need rather than a Griselbrand.

@DragonShinzui: No, you'll have a scry and a peek at the next card. You'll have an ETB trigger, you'll have a death trigger. You'll have a zombie creature card in the graveyard. You won't have to eat shit unless you enjoy that kind of thing, and please don't do it at the game table.

126153: Reality Strobe.author: Donovan_Fabian
126153: Reality Strobe.text_parsed:
Casting cost being ridiculous? I've played against these and to the contrary the card is ridiculous, it replays itself every couple turns. Even just 2 in play means your opponent never can keep a creature, and has half their land sent back to their hand pretty fast. This is one of the reasons blue is hard to keep fair, it either is very over powered because the only counter to blue is itself (counter spells can only be stopped by another counter spell, reality strobe can only be stopped by a counter spell, etc), or underpowered because it lacks the control it needs to not be over run.

Anyways, reality strobe is actually really nuts if anyone has ever seen it in play, no one ever hard casts it. Always suspend 3, preferably early in the game, and then continuing benefit until game ends.

126153: Reality Strobe.author: BloodJunkie
126153: Reality Strobe.text_parsed:
Great card. Makes a good combo with Paradox Haze and even Jhoira's Timebug.
Of course, its offset by its cost. But what ridiculously overpowered card isn't? I personally think this is the perfect cost for such a weapon of mass destruction.
I play 4 of these in a UR, bounce/burn/control deck. In said deck, I do not have Paradox Haze or Jhoira's Timebug. Early game I hit with Disperse, Lightning Bolt, Electrolyze and the like. My opponent rarely is able to play something substantial by the time I drop this, and by then, nothing is playable anymore. Then I take him/her out with Chronozoa or Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind.
Anyone who says this card is bad, has never seen it in play, or has never seen it used in combination with other bounce cards and counter spells. Burns are just a nice bonus in the mix. This card makes me LOL.
5/5

126153: Reality Strobe.author: DeadLeeCoC
126153: Reality Strobe.text_parsed:
@Donovan_Fabian

I agree with most of what you said, except for only "blue counters blue". The best answer for a blue counterspell is a black duress.

You pay one black cast duress, and either
a) you make them discard the counterspell, and get to see if they're holding another one.
b) they pay two mana and counter the duress, and have 2 less mana to cast the next counterspell with.


Either way, the counterspell is gone.



But yes, it is very difficult to keep blue balanced.

126153: Reality Strobe.author: spirit_of_blue
126153: Reality Strobe.text_parsed:
@DeadLeeCoC:
The best answer for a blue counterspell is a black duress.

It really depends on actual situation. Lets say both players have 4 cards in hand and black player would play duress only to see 4 various counterspells in blue players hand. 1 will be discarded and now both players have 3 cards in hand.

Philosophical mind games. Black player is happy for discarding counterspell, blue player is happy for "countering" for 0 mana, thus have open mana for next countering of real threat. Both players are happy for reaching their goal. ;-) Actually it is my "magic greenhorn years experience" from casual games with my friend we played many years ago. He had dedicated black discard deck, I had dedicated blue counterspell deck. Unless he tried discarding 2 for 1 like with Hymn to Tourach or Mind Rot, I did not bother countering 1 card discard spell as it was card for card.

@ Arachnos:
What happens if the last time counter is removed while there are no permanents on the field?

Spell does not have legal target and goes to graveyard. It will not be suspended again.

It does destroy creatures with protection from black and shroud. It also has no drawbacks to be played early in a mono black deck, you trade surprise for mana (because you can pay for it before the creature comes into play) its biggest flaw is you can't choose which creature to kill, they do.

126164: Judge Unworthy.author: HeartbreakerStudios
126164: Judge Unworthy.text_parsed:
The biggest drawback to this card is that you can only use it during the combat phase. Without that, this card would be 5/5.

As it stands, it's an okay card for dealing some moderate damage to enemies, while deck stacking at the same time, to prep draws and clashes.

I find, however, that it's remarkable capacity to target your own creatures makes it relatively invaluable for decks that pull damage eaters like Phytohydra.

Drop a Phytohydra for 5 mana and you've got a fairly vulnerable 1/1 creature. It's prone to non-damage -1/-1 counters, as well as debilitation. But on it's first block or attack, you can give it a massive jumpstart by targeting it with Judge Unworthy.

Consider: Revealing a 1 converted mana cost card with Judge Unworthy is the equivalent of a single use of Daily Regimen without the casting cost. Now consider revealing a second Phytohydra instead, with a converted mana cost of 5. That's 5 +1/+1 counters all for the cost the equivalent of a single use of Daily Regimen.

126165: Lymph Sliver.author: Calver
126165: Lymph Sliver.text_parsed:
The majority here is correct that absorb is very potent, especially when combined with pestilence-type abilities as noted. I'm not denying that at all.

But it really comes down to this: Lymph Sliver is 4W and prevents 1 damage; Ward Sliver is 4W and prevents all damage (and also provides limited evasion and shroud). Therefore, there is no reason to ever play this card while Ward Sliver is an option. That Ward Sliver only protects from a single color isn't even an argument. If your opponent is playing a multicolor deck, the only other cards they have that can eliminate your ward sliver are non-damage spells like boomerang, doom blade, or path to exile. All of these cards would get rid of the Lymph Sliver anyway!

So, like I said, Lymph Sliver is definitely a good card, but it's not the optimal pick.
(As an aside, if you're paranoid about your opponent multi-blocking, a 1-mana Sidewinder Sliver reduces the same amount of damage without preventing it, and makes your opponent's creatures easier to kill at the same time)

All of these cards would get rid of the Lymph Sliver anyway!

So, like I said, Lymph Sliver is definitely a [i]good[/i] card, but it's not the optimal pick.
(As an aside, if you're paranoid about your opponent multi-blocking, a 1-mana [autocard]Sidewinder Sliver[/autocard] reduces the same amount of damage without preventing it, and makes your opponent's creatures easier to kill at the same time)

126165: Lymph Sliver.author: Equinox523
126165: Lymph Sliver.text_parsed:
The fact that this is a sliver makes Absorb a far more interesting ability. This ability is a bit less interesting than it may initially seem - in almost all situations, it's effectively extra toughness. The only situations where it is not are:

- Effects like Pyrohemia, Pestilence and Prodigal Pyromancer which deal damage in tiny packets rather than big chunks.

- When actual toughness matters, such as blocking Mtenda Herder or interactions with spells like Blood Lust.

- "Vanilla matters" situations like Muraganda Petroglyphs.

(I'm sure there are more, but I just can't think of them off the bat).

If they were to reuse absorb, it would be handy in a set where toughness matters, or where things ping themselves or their allies a la Psionic Entity, helping mitigate the self-harm. I'm curious about whether or not Absorb will return.

126166: Llanowar Mentor.author: Mode
126166: Llanowar Mentor.text_parsed:
Cards with replacement effects when they get discarded generally only work if the source from the effect is from an opponent for reasons like that, Gezus82.

Nontheless i agree that the possibility to turn any card in hand into a Llanowar Elf (moreover: into permanent mana accel) is pretty useful.
In general directly using Llanowar Elves might be better, but when used along with the right cards this guy can be your friend.
Although Wilt-Leaf Liege won't work, there are many cards which come in handy for discarding, like cards with Madness or Incarnations - Anger in particular, which allows you to offset the mana required to produce a Llanowar Elf immediately by tapping it since it gets haste (given that you control a Mountain).

126166: Llanowar Mentor.author: Salient
126166: Llanowar Mentor.text_parsed:
Relentless Elves!

These "discard a card: get a copy of such-a-such card" cards are wonderful with Doubling Season.

Yes, I know, I know, everything and its brother is wonderful with Doubling Season. But the card advantage generated from this pairing is also good in an incremental Spike sense, not just a wildholycrap Johnny sense. Run creatures with Scavenge (Deadbridge Goliath), get 2-for-1 Llanowar Elves, use Scavenge activations to pump your creatures, and.

A million better Johnny combos exist, sure, but try this one from a competitive perspective -- it's not powerful enough to see tournament play, but it plays smoothly and incrementally in the way that a ramp Spike player will appreciate. Playing , Pack Rats are a good place to start...

If they know its coming it doesn't pack the same kind of power.

126169: Cyclical Evolution.author: Tommy9898
126169: Cyclical Evolution.text_parsed: Wonder why it costs so much to suspend. Not like suspend for one green would have broke the game.
126169: Cyclical Evolution.text_posted: [autocard]Wonder[/autocard] why it costs so much to suspend.  Not like suspend for one green would have broke the game.

126169: Cyclical Evolution.author: ultratog1028
126169: Cyclical Evolution.text_parsed:
SO BAD.

why?

1. 5 mana hard cast for a 1 mana effect.
2. If you suspend it, there is no guarantee that you'll have creatures when it resolves.
3. Overrun costs just as much and is much better, even if you have only one creature.
4. Sorcery speed/going off in the upkeep ensures that the creature will be blocked 90% of the time.
5. Even if you do suspend it, your opponent might do something that makes you not want to attack.
6. Takes too long to unsuspend.
7. If countered or if it doesn't have a legal target, it will NOT resuspend itself.

However, from the art, it appears as if this was intended to put 3 +1/+1 counters on a creature each time it was cast (Notice each Wurm coil growing larger each casting. that doesn't seem like temporary pump to me). If so, then this card would have been alright. Instead of bad.

126169: Cyclical Evolution.author: DarthParallax
126169: Cyclical Evolution.text_parsed:
Well, the first thing I'd like to say is, that with any of the 'basic effect' spells (pump, damage, destroy target, draw, life gain) you should ask yourselves: Why this, over any other card?

This is for +6/+6. it's delayed, and it's not as good as direct damage or counters, but it still has the potential to be a pretty big effect. I think that, considering it CAN be a Lava Axe if things go quite well for you, and that it does interact well with Manaplasm-types (which includes both casts being copyable), and that it can target different creatures, that is actually OK for the hard cast.

The knobs that I'm not sure whether they could turn a bit sharper are: number of time counters; suspend cost; speed; number of suspend turns.

3 turns and 3 counters is I think a harder cost than the cast. After all, Green is the color of mana dorks, and after looking at lots of high-costing cards that turned out to be plenty well playable because the effects were strong, if they had changed it to Suspend 1 and 1 Time Counter, then the card would have been very good. Also might have been a rare.

Instant vs. Sorcery speed is a tricky thing to judge. If this card has as much potential as I think it does, it may not need Instant speed. Sorcery speed pumping would normally want instant speed for combat tactics, but if you're pumping big enough, you can play pump like Lava Axe instead of like Lightning Bolt, and be fine.

Either changing how much time it takes to work, or changing the Suspend cost to to match Giant Growth, would have made this card twice as good as it is, and it's already playable. But remember- every little change on a card like this has more impact than you think it does, and changing it to:


Instant
1 time counter
Suspend 1

Would have been a LOT better than Giant Growth, and probably better than Overrun.

126193: Arc Blade.author: Mode
126193: Arc Blade.text_parsed:
Far too slow, even for limited.

A shock for five mana is very steep.
A shock for three mana with a three turn delay isn't any better.

Sure, it keeps coming back, but only at very slow intervals.
Sure, there are cards to decrease those intervals, but that just brings it on the level it should already have been.

Compare this to Rift Bolt, which does 150% of the damage for two mana each less regarding both costs, and with just a single turn delay (that might even be advantageous for you).
Or compare it to Staggershock, which is basically a second take on that idea, done right.

This could easily have dealt 3 damage (maybe even 4), or have its cost lowered to / Suspend 3 .

126200: Scout's Warning.author: Mode
126200: Scout's Warning.text_parsed:
Quicken for creatures, and a not abusable white version of Flash. I love that one.
Instant speed is more useful than some players might think, aside from an unsuspected blocker in general you can bring out a creature with cip/etb effect that might be devasting against your unprepared opponent.

And these shenanigans require nothing but a single white mana - you might even play it if you don't have the right creature in hand and hope for drawing it by casting this spell. That's a quite risky move, though.

Oh, and you can imprint it in Isochron Scepter as well for some cheap card advantage and more flashing creatures.

126200: Scout's Warning.author: Shiizu
126200: Scout's Warning.text_parsed:
A fixed Flash. It's a powerful and overlooked card.

As for why it is good:
1) You can keep your mana open to keep your opponent in check on his turn.(aka removal, counterspells and others)
2) You can force the control player to counter on his turn, thus giving you the opportunity to do whatever you want on your own turn.
3) You can flash in a creature that will block an incoming creature to death.
4) You can further abuse come into play effects.
5) You can play your bomb on the opponent's end step and give him very little time to respond to it.
6) When you're topdecking, this will act as a cycling card. So it's not a dead draw. If your deck is all creatures and instants, you will probably always do it on someone else's turn.

The only drawback to this card is that your creature costs one white mana extra, and that it isn't beyond broken like its older brother.

126200: Scout's Warning.text_parsed:
I rate this a five

Ignore the effect, look at the cost and the "Draw a Card", if it costs one, and says draw a card, it may be worth a slot in that colored deck.

Then it says instant, I mean compare it to blue draw, 3 mana for 2 cards? Scout's Warning is way too powerful (just kidding). But you can see how 1 mana for 1 card is looking good, now make it an instant and your deck can be ~56 cards

Lastly, the effect itself is super gold, I mean, flash a creature? That can be used in so many ways, it is awesome.

But my main point stands, this card is great where you can use its ability (of Flash) the fact that it could be used in quite a lot of decks as just filler makes it awesome.

Shiizu's excellent summary pretty much sums up my thoughts on this card. It's quite potent and gives you the element of surprise for an extra , or is simply a cycler when you need cards badly. I should mention some fun things you can do with this:

Typhoid Rats: Deathtouching blocker.
Academy Researchers or Iridescent Drake: Aura-ed creature entering the battlefield.
Bone Shredder or Fleshbag Marauder: Instant removal.
Man-o'-War: Instant bounce.
Eternal Witness: Instant retrieval.
Cosmic Larva: Huge cheap blocker, optional whether or not you want to keep it next turn.

There are a ton more, but this is a fun card that has a lot of potential. Also, Crag-Hack's Sunblast Angel trick is just nasty.

126201: Shivan Sand-Mage.author: LordRandomness
126201: Shivan Sand-Mage.text_parsed: First turn, suspend a sand mage. Second turn, suspend two. Third turn, suspend another one plus Wheel of Fate. Fourth turn, drop a bunch of cheap burn and preferably something to wipe the board so your opponent doesn't kill you. Fifth turn, first mage resolves. Have it target the second one. Have the second one target the third one. Have the third one target the fourth one. Have the fourth one target Wheel of Fate, resolving it (it's got two counters left). Swing with your four hasty 3/2s and enjoy the reloaded hand with all your mana untapped!

126201: Shivan Sand-Mage.author: BloodDragon
126201: Shivan Sand-Mage.text_parsed:
On average your opponent will cast a spell a turn for the first few turns.

Turn 1: Suspend Shivan Sand-Mage
Turn 2: Suspend Pardic Dragon
Turn 3: Other things
Turn 4: Pardic Dragon with haste + Other things

If he's managed to squeeze another spell in there then he's forced to keep playing out his hand or deal with a 4/4, or if he's keeping back some removal, it will free you up to play a bigger threat on turn 4 with your unspent mana.

Not great, there might even be better targets for the sand mage but the panic of an impending threat on your opponents face when you slap this down in the first two turns. That might just be worth it.
Casual 1 on 1s.

126210: River of Tears.author: Reliquium
126210: River of Tears.text_parsed:
So the first turn you play this, you get . Then the choice is whether to play a land before you tap it to get or play a land after you tap it to get ...it's a neat concept. Is it ever useful, though?

The art is spectacular, and suits this frame so well, as a few cards from this set do. Some cards completely clash with it, like Grove of the Burnwillows, which hurts the eyes, or Horizon Canopy, where the blue-green of the frame and the yellow-green of the art clash subtly and wash out the whole card. But I think this is the prettiest MAGIC card I've seen.

Other nice ones with Future Sight frames are Bitter Ordeal, Korlash, Heir to Blackblade, and Blade of the Sixth Pride suits full-frame so well; the art reminds me of Sam Keith (of The Maxx comic book fame).

126210: River of Tears.author: jonrds
126210: River of Tears.text_parsed:
If this doesn't get reprinted in Journey into Nyx I'm going to be so angry. What set could be better?

Update: It looks like River of Tears is very specifically from the plane "Arkhos". From "The Planes of Planechase":

"Arkhos is the plane represented by the Future Sight card River of Tears (also illustrated by Chris J. Anderson). It's a dreamlike world where night and day intermingle according to its own strange internal logiccheck out the delicate quality of the light in the art. Near Lethe Lake on Arkhos, memories ebb away like the current of an old stone watercourse. Most mages tend to steer clear of the psychic ravages of the Lake, but surprisingly, some seek it out, believing they need to be cleansed of all remnants of the past in order to make their minds free for new magical creations."

126211: Darksteel Garrison.author: Mode
126211: Darksteel Garrison.text_parsed:
The concept of fortifications seems interesting, but the use of them (at least now) seems to be lower.

The idea behind equipment is that you can use it on multiple creatures, either because the old wielder died or because you've cast one that can make better use of it.
But how should the land 'die' if it's indestructible?
When should you want to switch the fortification? The +1/+1 bonus from tapping is independant from the land, and i can't imagine too many lands that need to be protected that much more than the one you've previously spent 3 mana on and which will get destructible again.

Overall this card feels too expensive to me, especially when compared to Darksteel Plate this feels less usefull.
It also totally bugs me that this card is something made of Darksteel and not indestructible itself.
Manlands could make good use of this, though. But that's the only good use i could imagine:

In general you don't have to fear for your lands getting destroyed.
Aside from Wasteland (and Strip Mine) in eternal formats, where it often sees play, e.g. to destroy a dual land.
But in that case spending five mana won't really help since the Wasteland would just pick another Dual, so you could as well have used land search for that amount.

It can be useful to protect utility lands like Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth, Academy Ruins or Gaea's Cradle.
But why not simply use Consecrate Land for instead? Less decks have enchantment removal than artifact removal, and as aforementioned the general idea of fortifications doesn't seem that relevant in the case of Darksteel Garrison.

Since this is (currently) rated more than 3.75, it feels like i'm missing something...

Well, maybe one day when the third Mirrodin block comes out,
with a new array of lands and interactions with fortifications,
when we get riggers that assemble contraptions for us,
this card might once in a sudden appear a whole lot more useful.
126211: Darksteel Garrison.text_posted:

The idea behind equipment is that you can use it on multiple creatures, either because the old wielder died or because you've cast one that can make better use of it.
But how should the land 'die' if it's indestructible?
When should you want to switch the fortification? The +1/+1 bonus from tapping is independant from the land, and i can't imagine too many lands that need to be protected that much more than the one you've previously spent 3 mana on and which will get destructible again.

Overall this card feels too expensive to me, especially when compared to [autocard]Darksteel Plate[/autocard] this feels less usefull.
It also totally bugs me that this card is something made of Darksteel and [i]not[/i] indestructible itself.
Manlands could make good use of this, though. But that's the only good use i could imagine:

In general you don't have to fear for your lands getting destroyed.
Aside from [autocard]Wasteland[/autocard] (and [autocard]Strip Mine[/autocard]) in eternal formats, where it often sees play, e.g. to destroy a dual land.
But in that case spending five mana won't really help since the Wasteland would just pick another Dual, so you could as well have used land search for that amount.

It can be useful to protect utility lands like [autocard]Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth[/autocard], [autocard]Academy Ruins[/autocard] or [autocard]Gaea's Cradle[/autocard].
But why not simply use [autocard]Consecrate Land[/autocard] for [W] instead? Less decks have enchantment removal than artifact removal, and as aforementioned the general idea of fortifications doesn't seem that relevant in the case of Darksteel Garrison.

Since this is (currently) rated more than 3.75, it feels like i'm missing something...

Well, maybe one day when the third Mirrodin block comes out,
with a new array of lands and interactions with fortifications, 
when we get [autocard multiverseid="136151"]riggers that assemble contraptions[/autocard] for us,
this card might once in a sudden appear a whole lot more useful.

I believe they cast Darksteel. The banning of this card still annoys me, from what i have heard and read, this card wasnt broken, it just broke another card, thopter foundry, first they were gonna ban that but didnt want to ban a card that just came out so banned this instead. which means if you use thopter foundry its fine (I find it way more powerful than this) but if you pull out this card by itself you get a hailstorm of hate from everyone else who thinks it is 10 times more of a threat than it really is solely on the fact it is banned. grrrr

126215: Sword of the Meek.author: ICEFANG13
126215: Sword of the Meek.text_parsed:
I think this card sucks, other than the combo.

2 to cast and equip, toughness increases usually are less desirable than abilities, and in my experience, most 'ok' equipment never ends up in the graveyard, let alone bad equipment.

If you get it in your graveyard and play a 1/1 turn one, which are somewhat uncommon in my experience, then you can have a 2/3? Doesn't that seem like a waste of time to work on?

1/5 alone, maybe .5, there is just no reason to abuse it, and no reason to use it normally.

Now with combos, you can have something to sac over and over, free back to play can be great, but only because of what you can do with it that gives his card any potential. I'm sticking with 1/5, I generally don't like rating a card only based on combos, this one, since I don't see it being used in things other than combos, gets some weird average.

Honestly I can't see a 4 for this, can anyone get any combos that really matter? How about any non instant win ones? (I think comboing with cards is sweet, instant win ones are a lot more boring)

126215: Sword of the Meek.author: Patep
126215: Sword of the Meek.text_parsed:
This is more synergy then a combo, but one of my friends runs this in an infect deck, and her favorite thing to put this on is an ichorclaw myr. That way it is a 2/3 with infect, but if it is blocked its suddenly a 4/5. She also runs trading post because these three cards (while not a combo) make trading post insane.
Trading post in her deck
Ability 1: Discard sword of the meek, gain four life
Ability 2: Pay 1 life get a free blocker.
Ability 3: Sacrifice goat or other useless creature, get an ichorclaw for other trading post back from the graveyard.
ability 4: Sac a sword of the meek, get card advantage.

In her infect deck, she uses these abilities at instant speed (especially when she is chump blocking) and she did awesome things.

At one point she had two untapped trading posts, and the enemy played shatter storm. She sacrificed the first TP to itself, then she sacrificed an artifact creature (using the creature sac ability) to pull the first out of the graveyard into her hand, and on her turn played an ichorclaw myr and the TP from her hand, and oh by the way 3 swords of the meek were in her graveyard so that was a 4/7 with infect that when blocked becomes a 6/9. ^_^ These are just a few ways the deck was screwing with the opponent.

BTW as a good balance, i play with sword of the meek and thopter foundry in one of my decks, but as a house rule we say if it hits the graveyard twice in one turn, the second time it is exiled.

126215: Sword of the Meek.author: Missile_Penguin
126215: Sword of the Meek.text_parsed:
Nearly every card in Time Spiral block was a throwback to at least one previously printed card.

This card references Aegis of the Meek, which preceded equipment and used an older template in an attempt to represent creatures wielding weapons. These swords both reference Pendelhaven and belonged to Jacques le Vert, one of the original protectors of Pendelhaven, and can be seen in his art.

This card is actually banned in the Modern format because of its incredibly synergistic effect with Thopter Foundry.

These swords both reference [autocard]Pendelhaven[/autocard] and belonged to [autocard]Jacques le Vert[/autocard], one of the original protectors of Pendelhaven, and can be seen in his art.

130314: Skirk Ridge Exhumer.author: Silverware
130314: Skirk Ridge Exhumer.text_parsed:
I have had mixed feelings about this card. I love the concept of being able to play a festering goblin each turn by just keeping this guy out and throwing down a each turn. Though to be realistic, a 1/1 body on this guy makes him an easy target to get rid of. Also if there is only this and festering goblins on the field then this guy will die (since no matter what he will be hit for -1/-1). If this guy is not on the field and one of your goblins get zaped and only festering goblins are on the field then all your goblins die.

I personaly feel that zombie tribal needs to play fast and sadly this guy does not feel like he plays fast enough. His ability is amazing in its own right, but it is slow and risky in zombies. I feel that almost every card you play in an aggro deck needs to be able to do somthing the turn you play it.

This is a great card, it really is. Just a tad bit slower than I would like.

130314: Skirk Ridge Exhumer.author: Krysto
130314: Skirk Ridge Exhumer.text_parsed:
Turn 1: Swamp + Putrid Imp
Turn 2: Swamp + Exhumer - Discard Dread Return to make the imp fly
Turn 3: Swamp - Use the Exhumer to discard a big baddie (pref 11/11 monstrosity). - Flashback it
Turn 4: Mutilate

The problem here is that without some finesse, the Exhumer doesn't help you *that* much, but the point is, it cheaply drops cards from your hand into the grave, gives you a Festering Goblin to play with, and ultimately gives you body fodder for cards like Dread Return, which REALLY benefits from killing the goblins, and as a result means you can have your late game killers out even earlier.

This same strategy with a T1 kickstart from a Dark Ritual means you can have baddies on the field from cards like Animate Dead sooner then ever with the added benefit of an extra Goblin to boot.

Also hilarious in casual.

130320: Saltskitter.author: Polyphemos
130320: Saltskitter.text_parsed:
Fun casual combo with this card: Worldslayer, Pollenbright Wings, Brass Squire to equip the Worldslayer for free, and probably a mana ramp to speed things up. Stick the sword and the wings on Saltskitter, and you'll likely get through with flying. Let the Wings resolve first, and you'll get three 1/1 tokens, causing Saltskitter to phase out. Then let Worldslayer wipe the board, and Saltskitter should phase back in at the end of your turn, with a path open to attack.

So there you have it, a use for the Saltskitter. Not the best combo, sure, but it's fun.
130320: Saltskitter.text_posted:

130320: Saltskitter.author: Nagazel
130320: Saltskitter.text_parsed:
As a card on its own Saltskitter is not the best creature by a long shot. But I run Saltskitter in a deck with Norin, the Wary, Leyline of Vitality, Genesis Chamber, Pandemonium, Enchanted Evening to great effect. Once you have a Norin and Saltskitter out you let the 'Skitter hit the field first then Norin follow. Skitter leaves immediately and does so every turn. Once the deck gets going it gets hilarious. And nothing says fun like Mirrorweave as a field wipe using your Saltskitter to exile all other creatures in play.

I like it. Good flavor and not easily exploitable but it has solid combo potential.

130320: Saltskitter.author: Fanaticmogg
130320: Saltskitter.text_parsed:
This card can beat for 3, which is worth having in Limited on top of its ETB-trigger shenanigans. Also, Flash creatures let it dodge removal.

"But Fanaticmogg, what if I want to play a creature? Then he gets exiled and I don't get to attack!"

You should be playing cards after combat anyways. In fact, since it comes back untapped, playing creatures after it attacks gives it pseudo-Vigilance, as long as your opponent doesn't have any creatures to play. So, really bad pseudo-vigilance, which is still better than nothing.

It's kinda like Norin the Wary, but it's actualy capable of attacking.

130320: Saltskitter.author: blurrymadness
130320: Saltskitter.text_parsed:
The flavor of it is amazing! (It hides when creatures come by)
He's not bad for convincing opponents to drop creatures in their first main phase to attack through and he's also not bad as a difficult to remove creature (if you have ways of adding tokens to the battlefield at instant speed.)

It doesn't require combos to be good; just a little deckbuilding synergy; making him a fun casual card that can still fit into a reasonably powerful deck.

It's also worth noting he has psuedo-vigilance; which is also flavorful.

130328: Haze of Rage.author: DarthParallax
130328: Haze of Rage.text_parsed:
This is as blatant as they come:

A powerful effect, IF maxed.
Costs lots of mana.
Includes two very old abilities that pair well together.
Costs an assload and a half of mana to use to full effect.

Fellow Planeswalkers:
Strictly Excellent in EDH, almost bad elsewhere. It's got a great amount of potential, no doubts there, but most of its power is only accessible under circumstances that are hard to encounter outside of EDH or other Kitchen Table formats. Definitely scores high on the fun scale when it works though :)
12/4/2011

EDIT: a year and a half later, I thought of a better way of wording what I meant: it's basically a mana-dump storm card, much like lots of storm cards, BUT I think it's probably a lot more fair than most storm cards while still not being broke. 3-stars is a good rating for it, and I like this card. :)

130331: Wrap in Vigor.author: Piedmont
130331: Wrap in Vigor.text_parsed:
@ubii: It only taps if the creature is dealt damage to destroy it (rules 2010, possibly earlier). The definition of regeneration is "Regenerate *permanent*" means "The next time *permanent* would be destroyed this turn, instead remove all damage from it, tap it, and (if it's in combat) remove it from combat."

One could regenerate it during their upkeep and use it just fine for that turn until it's dealt lethal damage or destroyed then it will tap. New rules also mean regeneration has to be up before damage is dealt, which is the declare blockers step in combat or "in response" to a spell/effect.

First strike is a problem for regenerators, notice the text removed from combat. If a first striker does enough damage and you have a regeneration shield, your creature will be regenerated and removed from combat, having done none back to the first striker. I use regeneration in Magic Online, the declare blockers step is the last moment they will let me regenerate my creature to save it. I have also accidentally regenerated my creature during my main phase and it didn't tap as for the reasons above.

So, this spell will only tap those creatures destroyed or dealt lethal damage this turn and the ones that aren't will remain untapped. Imagine if regeneration did tap without lethal/destroy damage, you could cast a nurturing licid, use it on opponents indestructible creature, and during their upkeep keep regenerating causing their creature to be tapped and out of the way pretty much indefinetely. But, it doesn't work like that :)

130332: Lost Hours.author: NARFNra
130332: Lost Hours.text_parsed:
@Achumbokum
While it does cost one more, this card does three things Duress doesn't:

1: It allows you to get rid of annoying creatures that could mess you up(e.g. Demigod Of Revenge, Baneslayer Angel, etc.)
2: It gets by reanimation decks.
3: It uses up one of their draws, although not their next one.

All in all, I personally like Lost Hours more. Duress deals with Counterspells far better, though.

I really don't understand why this card is downrated so hard. Whatever you target is gone for some time and if you're using some mill (in which black is second best) it's gone forever. Even when they draw the card after three turns they lose a draw.
In my opinion it's better than Distress and maybe even preferable over Duress in any deck which uses mill (which does not even mean that the deck must include blue due to the many mill-artifacts there are today: Codex Shredder, Ghoulcaller's Bell, Grindclock, Mindcrank, etc.) Also LordRandomness made a good point.

130338: Thunderblade Charge.author: Catmurderer
130338: Thunderblade Charge.text_parsed: How do you do the second part of this card ie pay 2RRR and "play it without paying its mana cost"?

130338: Thunderblade Charge.author: Elysiume
130338: Thunderblade Charge.text_parsed:
The second part works because you are paying the cost to use the ability that allows you to cast it. You then get to use it without paying it's mana cost. It's the same as if it said "you may pay 2RRR to cast it." It's just for clarity and whatnot.

It's pretty good, and fairly fun. If you have leftover mana sitting around you can burn it on damage, which is always nice.

130347: Seht's Tiger.author: BayushiKazemi
130347: Seht's Tiger.text_parsed:
This is pretty amusing. It's like a color-focused fog.

@ Dingo777
Actually, since the card gives you protection from red you are no longer a legal target. If a spell has no legal targets it fizzles (counters itself, even if it is uncounterable). If you gave yourself Protection from Red before they played the Banefire, they would not be allowed to target you with it (ditto for Progenitus). Thus, it is not a question of preventing the damage but rather a question of whether the targets are legal.
I reference rule 607.2b of the Comprehensive rulebook.

If you gave yourself Protection from Red before they played the Banefire, they would not be allowed to target you with it (ditto for Progenitus). 130347: Seht's Tiger.author: kiseki
130347: Seht's Tiger.text_parsed:
Banefire is an interesting case, because if it could resolve against a player with protection from red, the damage would get through the pro red, since protection prevents damage. That point is moot since Banefire only has one target and the target must be legal on declaration and resolution, and it won't be legal on resolution so it will be countered.
A fireball with two targets will not be countered unless both targets become illegal though.

130353: Riftsweeper.author: A3Kitsune
130353: Riftsweeper.text_parsed:
Along with nixing Suspended cards (he combos well with Delay), he turns temporary exile spells and effects like Turn to Mist and Mistmeadow Witch's ability into "shuffle into owner's library", and gets rid of stuff that was only exiled until the permanent that exiled it (for instance, a Champion creature) leaves play.
He's also anti-Imprint tech (or a way to get back your own Imprinted cards if something happens to the Imprinting artifact).

130353: Riftsweeper.author: Flash.Blue.Dog
130353: Riftsweeper.text_parsed:
@ Gilder_Bairn
It was unbanned because the General Zone is now a separate zone from the Exiled zone, so you cannot Riftsweeper a general from the General Zone into it's owner's library. However, if for some reason the player allows the General to go to the Exiled zone, then yes, you could Riftsweeper it in the owner's library. All in all, still a damn fine card. At worst it is a Grizzly Bears that is tribal elf, at best it gets you back an Exiled creature of yours or shuffles a suspend card into a library. Was really good in Future Sight draft to stop suspend stuff.

130564: Nix.author: remnant_phoenix
130564: Nix.text_parsed:
I'm surprised it hasn't been said in comment yet, but this card can counter ANY suspended spell that is coming into play. Suspend specifically says that when the last counter is removed, "play the card without paying its mana cost." That's the main point of this card.

If I was running blue and playing Time Spiral block constructed I would at least sideboard a playset if I didn't main deck. Most of the best stuff in the block came from playing suspended spells. Countering those for one blue is really good. Yes it's a niche card, only really useful in Time Spiral block, but in that niche it is excellent.

This card would have been much better, all-around, if it had cost 0.

There was perfect symmetry right there in the designers face and they whiffed.

130564: Nix.author: Cubozoan
130564: Nix.text_parsed:
This card could almost be considered as part of a vertical cycle:
Mental Misstep - Common that cares about CMC 1
Spell Snare - Uncommon that cares about CMC 2
Nix - Rare that cares about CMC 0

Some day I'd like to build a deck of very picky counterspells like these, as well as others like Intervene, Confound, Spell Pierce, and Second Guess. With enough card draw and transmute support, as well as maybe some Essence Scatters and Dissipates to smooth out the corners, every game would be like solving a puzzle!

Part of an innovative cycle from Future Sight:

: Nimbus Maze
: River of Tears
: Graven Cairns
: Horizon Canopy
: Grove of the Burnwillows

130582: Char-Rumbler.author: Psuedonaut
130582: Char-Rumbler.text_parsed:
Wild Pair a 1/1(Myr Moonvessel, Memnite) or a 0/2(Ornithopter) for this guy. That is all. Wait, no it isn't!
Braid of Fire. I think that's all.
Wait!
It's not!
Rancor + Giant Growth + Berserk.
Assuming you pumped him up 3 times because of Braid, he'll be a 2/3, then a 4/3 with trample, then a 7/6 with trample, then a 14/6 with trample. And double strike. I.e. 28 damage. 3 green mana, the three red from Braid of Fire, and assuming you got him out with Wild Pair, he becomes a BAMF.
Also, if you think Wild Pair is too expensive, consider this, Red has Pyretic Ritual, Desperate Ritual, Rite of Flame, and Seething Song. Let's not forget, since you're also green, you've got all that mana ramp at your disposal. Especially if you get all those 1/1 elves(see; Skyshroud Elf, when you've got Wild pair, bam, throw down an elf and you've got Mr.Rumbly. That's if braid's been out three turns. If it's out four turns.... you've got another.

If he dies.... Withstand Death instead of Rancor.

Might actually make a deck around this guy.

130582: Char-Rumbler.author: Mode
130582: Char-Rumbler.text_parsed:
You'd think they'd add a reminder text to clarify what happens if he hits with -1 power.
Because it's not like this is a common thing to have on a creature.
(Although in fact it's not the only one to have a negative power.)

I'm pretty sure there have been some kitchen table debates about him already; where players wondered if he could increase an opponent's life, or a blocking creature's defense. (He doesn't, he'll simply deal no damage.)

As a reference, here are the rules about negative numbers:

104.1b Most of the time, the Magic game uses only positive numbers. You cant choose a negative number, deal negative damage, gain negative life, and so on. However, its possible for a game value, such as a creatures power, to be less than zero. If a calculation or comparison that would determine the result of an effect needs to use a negative value, it does so. If such a calculation yields a negative number, zero is used instead, unless that effect sets a players life total to a specific value, sets a creatures power or toughness to a specific value, or otherwise modifies a creatures power or toughness.

So another notable thing is that if you use him in a deck with Soulblast,
his negative power will actually reduce the total amount of damage - it's not simply always treated as zero.

So another notable thing is that if you use him in a deck with [autocard]Soulblast[/autocard],
his negative power will actually [i]reduce[/i] the total amount of damage - it's not simply always treated as zero.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: Spideredd
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Is this Card for real?
An uncommon with this power?
Channel Shinen of Life's Roar onto Sylvan Basilisk just before you attack with this card to end your opponents game.

and in case you're wondering, casting Giant Growth will affect all of the copies of Nacatl War-Pride, as supported by rule 706.4. which is specific in mentioning Giant Growth as an example. A ssuming, of course, that you cast it in your main phase, as opposed to your combat phase, as otherwise, the tokens would be 3/3 and Nacatl War-Pride would be 6/6

however, with Spirit Link rule 706.2 states that it is only the creature that is copied, not the effects from another card, unless it causes a change to power/toughness.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: kiseki
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Some amount of strategy should go into this since it is very likely the original will get blocked with the biggest defending creature. However, if you get to attack on the following turn, it is often disappointing because you are getting fewer tokens that time around.
The thing many people don't realize until they have used it is that if all the tokens go in the direction of the original, then you have one more cat than your opponent has creatures. How has no one mentioned Might of the Masses yet? It can save the original, but better yet, whichever token gets through is huge.
This can also be brutal in multiplayer since you attack the person with the most creatures and then send the tokens in all directions to lay waste to the entire plane.

Also, combo with Garruk's Packleader for a freakton of cards.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: mn6334
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed: @GrimjawxRULES: You said it yourself, the tokens copy the ORIGINAL creature. When a creature has an ability that says it's name then you should read it as "This card". This card is a 3/3 creature that must be blocked by one creature if able and creates tokens of itself when it attacks. Temporary buffs like Giant Growth and abilities given to this creature do not change anything about this card and will not transfer over to the copies. The tokens will be 3/3 creatures that must be blocked by one creature if able ability and have the copy ability. (As for Spideredd quoting rule 706.4, that rule says that the Giant Growth is played on the creature doing the copying not the creature that is being copied, 706.2 is the rule that is in effect here.)

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: moriar
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Sundial of the Infinite.

Attack, get a bunch of copies in play. Any of the tokens that survive combat will put a triggered ability on the stack at the beginning of the end of turn step.

Activate the Sundial of the Infinite in response to the triggered abilities, causing them to be removed from the stack.

The tokens survive the turn, to make more of themselves next turn, and further turns.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: Lief098
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:

Actually, extra combat phases will do almost nothing for this guy. If you look closely, you'll see that the tokens he produces in the first combat phase don't have haste, so they won't be able to attack on the second combat phase. The only thing you get with a second combat phase is a chance to make more copies with the original, unless you have some way to give your stuff haste (I'm looking at you, Urabrask).

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: voyager1
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
An extremely fun "Johnny" card that demands to be built around. By itself, the War-Pride is a little weak for the mana; it will probably take out a utility creature or two with it's first swing, while getting annihilated by an opponent's larger creature. But adding a few support cards makes it absurd.

I hadn't thought of Pandemonium and Garruk's Packleader before reading this thread, and they're even better than what I had in mind. Goblin War Drums, Bedlam, Vigor, and/or Door of Destinies were some of my own ideas (with Forbidden Orchard to get a few extra tokens). Whichever path you take, the War-Pride can create a huge effect with a single swing.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Champion of Lambholt
Opponent has, let's say, 4 creatures. They're 5/5s. Swing with Nacatl War-Pride and the champion (who already has +1/+1 from the original Necatl War-Pride).
4 copies of Necatl War-Pride come into play, so Champion gets 4 +1/+1 counters, meaning the 5/5s can't block your 5 Necatl War-Prides or the 6/6 Champion.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: Ragamander
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Nacatl War-Pride is one of the coolest cards in Magic: The Gathering, in my opinion. Everything about it makes it interesting as opposed to just bluntly powerful. A high mana cost and low power/toughness are offset by a blocker restriction that makes defending against it tricky and a massive self-cloning trigger that seems capable of ending games. The question is how to make that happen, and the War-Pride does a fantastic job balancing that potential for abuse with its overall power level (>9000 if your opponent has at least 3000 creatures).

I second the wonderful suggestions to use this with Champion of Lambholt, Sundial of the Infinite, and/or Parallel Lives.

Although Champion of Lambholt is probably the coolest suggestion for unblockability (and Bellowing Tanglewurm is pretty sweet too), Bedlam and Falter are also good options, especially with them being less vulnerable to typical removal. They're red, though. You could also combo Yavimaya Dryad and Lumbering Satyr, with the advantage being that it's respectably ridiculous.

I also agree that Cytoshape (in response to the token-creating triggered ability) would be amusing. Id Cytoshape the War-Pride into a Craterhoof Behemoth.

Speaking of making copies of the wrong thing, has anyone else thought about following this with Essence of the Wild? Not that it's that great, since they still don't have any sort of evasion, but comboing two cards with the same unusual mana cost does amuse me. Hey, and Vigor would stop the original War-Pride from getting killed in combat...

Also, I'd love to play Nacatl War-Pride with a few Renegade Doppelgangers and Clones thereof. Heat Shimmer would also work, I guess, but it'll only last a turn. Really, I just want to attack with multiple Nacatl War-Prides at once, ideally before my opponent has a chance to figure out what I'm up to. Like by using Dual Nature/Wild Pair and Concordant Crossroads...or by using Mirrorweave with mana dorks and weenies aplenty. And for multi-turn overkill, there's always Infinite Reflection. Even a measly 2 vs. 3 matchup sends at least 15 damage through, and if you used Mirrorweave, all blocks will be lethal to everything involved...unless you happen to have Leyline of Vitality or some other toughness-booster. Cool story bro.

While we're overkilling, we might as well run Coat of Arms. It's actually pretty good with Nacatl War-Pride on its own. If your opponent is playing tribal, it'll almost even out, but if they aren't playing tribal and you have some way of forcing the combat damage through, it'll be devastating. Too bad green is so bad at giving all its creatures trample.


One problem with Nacatl War-Pride though is that it doesn't really do its thing all that well if your opponent doesn't have enough creatures. Hunted Troll seems like the simplest way to fix that problem, but the more devious option is Natural Affinity/Living Plane. If you go down that road, consider Veteran Explorer, Collective Voyage/New Frontiers. If you want to send damage through, you could use Mana Web to try to keep them tapped down.

Another problem is how the original War-Pride will likely end up dead, meaning its first attack will be its last. Unblockability, at least for the original, is probably the best solution, but Lifeline will also probably work, since you will always be attacking with at least one more attacker than they have blockers, meaning that at least one will probably survive combat, which gives it a chance to make it to the end of the turn and revive all dead creatures (including your opponent's too, which is unfortunate unless you want them to have larger numbers of creatures for some reason). Any card with the "Populate" mechanic - especially Rootborn Defenses - is another option, since Populate can create a token Nacatl War-Pride that won't be exiled with the other tokens and won't be in combat. Trostani, Selesnya's Voice seems good too, due to the massive, massive life gain.

Overall, though, it's a fun, interesting card that inspires people to find ways to tap its hidden potential. The Time Spiral Block was a gold mine of creative card design like this, and I'm sad the developers didn't see fit to bring this chunk of pure gold back for the Alara Block.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: trickjoker
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed: Sundial DOES work. If you use it correctly. "At the beginning of the next end step" is a delayed trigger that will only happen once. If you wait until your end step, the exile trigger for each token goes on the stack. Trigger on stack, off goes sundial. Ends turn, exiling all triggers. Creatures stay.

130588: Nacatl War-Pride.author: endersblade
130588: Nacatl War-Pride.text_parsed:
Sundial of the Infinite

Swing. Make your tokens. At the start of your end step, after the exile triggers go on the stack, use the Sundial. Your tokens get to stay.

The beauty of this? The next time you swing with all of them, THEY ALL MAKE TOKENS. Every one of them is a copy of this card, therefore they all make copies of themselves, tapped and attacking. This gets out of hand very quickly (or the game is over, one of the two).

The beauty of this?  The next time you swing with all of them, THEY ALL MAKE TOKENS.  Every one of them is a copy of this card, therefore they all make copies of themselves, tapped and attacking.  This gets out of hand very quickly (or the game is over, one of the two).

130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.author: Donovan_Fabian
130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.text_parsed: Even though this was played with punishing fire for an awesome effect.. I still don't like it.  Your stuck with colorless or giving your opponent extra life, and anyone thats played with soul warden knows that can add up.  Sooner or later someone will find out a trick around that strategy, as they always do, and then it will be back to giving your opponents life for using colored mana.  I'd much rather play something like a sunpetal grove, that doesn't even come into play tapped if you have a forest or plains.  As far as removal goes.. punishing fire is awesome, but there are other ways to get repeating burn without resorting to that individual combo.

130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.author: Kbot
130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.text_parsed: Amazing that people don't think that this card plus Punishing Fire is good. The point is not to burn them every turn, the point is to dominate board position which is how you win every standard game. This is recursive removal without even the drawback of losing life which is more punishing vs. pure aggro/burn decks than having your opponent gain a measly 1 life. To put into perspective of the types of recursive damage removal spells R&D is willing to print, take a look at Razor Boomerang or Beacon of Destruction.
130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.text_posted: Amazing that people don't think that this card plus [autocard]Punishing Fire[/autocard] is good. The point is not to burn them every turn, the point is to dominate board position which is how you win every standard game. This is [b]recursive removal[/b] without even the drawback of losing life which is more [i]punishing[/i] vs. pure aggro/burn decks than having your opponent gain a measly 1 life. To put into perspective of the types of recursive damage removal spells R&D is willing to print, take a look at [autocard]Razor Boomerang[/autocard] or [autocard]Beacon of Destruction[/autocard].

130595: Grove of the Burnwillows.text_parsed:
In addition to the combo potential, this card is really good. Assuming you're playing with other lands, most of the time you can use the colorless ability, but the R/G one is there just in case, such as early on. That will only lead to a small amount of life. The only downside is that these two colors care the most about the opponent's life total.

4.5/5

But the art is absolutely gorgeous. It's one of my favorite land arts.

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: Donovan_Fabian
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed:
This card actually isn't that good, it costs slightly more than gaea's anthem, and on top of that most decks usually do play with creatures that have abilities, where otherwise it only works on tokens. Sigil captain is technically the better card for token purposes as its a creature instead of an enchantment so it can beat down on its own, and it gives out counters instead of straight up power increase so if it leaves the field the tokens stay large. Juniper order range also helps in that regard except that it costs 5 mana so it isn't quite as easy to play.

It can still get pretty out of control if you have a token producer that stays in play for a while, but then your probably winning anyways.

The one value this card has over all those other options, is an aggro deck, playing cards like watchwolf and some of those basic aggressive creatures without abilities.
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_posted:
This card actually isn't that good, it costs slightly more than gaea's anthem, and on top of that most decks usually do play with creatures that have abilities, where otherwise it only works on tokens.  Sigil captain is technically the better card for token purposes as its a creature instead of an enchantment so it can beat down on its own, and it gives out counters instead of straight up power increase so if it leaves the field the tokens stay large.  Juniper order range also helps in that regard except that it costs 5 mana so it isn't quite as easy to play.

It can still get pretty out of control if you have a token producer that stays in play for a while, but then your probably winning anyways.

The one value this card has over all those other options, is an aggro deck, playing cards like watchwolf and some of those basic aggressive creatures without abilities.

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: Arglypuff
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed: Actually, Gwafa, yes, it would have been a crime to add Trample. Let's say I have a bunch of 1/1s with no abilities (Humility in in play, for example). Then all of these 1/1s become 3/3s, and (if trample were added by the card), then the tokens become 3/3 tramplers. But then all of my 3/3 tramplers become 1/1s with no abilities again, because Trample is an ability. If this card gave trample, this card would be UTTERLY useless.

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: BegleOne
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed:
I waited forever for this card to be printed, because it does nullify so many "strictly better" arguments. But I was disappointed when I saw it; to be powerful it needs to cost less or boost more. +2/+2 for 4 isn't going to help much when you're entire strategy is around attacking with vanilla creatures. It is hard to get creatures through that have no evasion, haste, protection or shroud. It's such a weak strategy in the first place that you need a lot more than +2/+2 for 4 for it to be viable.

Tokens might be what scared Wizards about the concept, but I don't see how it's much more than a win-more card in a token deck that's doing its thing.

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: wstonefi
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed:
I hope they make a Muraganda expansion someday. I don't know how the mechanics would work -- "vanilla matters" isn't a very exciting theme, after all -- but the setting has some really awesome flavor. Prehistoric fantasy is made of win.

For anyone who cares, the two other cards from Muraganda are Imperiosaur and The Mimeoplasm. The Mimeoplasm's character bio, found in his Commander deck, also provides some cool info about the plane:

"Little is known about the bizarre entity that crawls the world of Muraganda. The fang druids call it the Mimeoplasm, as it absorbs the traits of anything it engulfs. The saurid warriors of the south seek out the Mimeoplasm wherever it roams, believing it to be the key to a mysterious afterlife, hoping to see in it traces of their fallen loved ones. The elves of the tropics believe it to be part of nature's cycle, a way to channel death back into life. The scarwitches hiss when it approaches, seeing it as the ultimate enemy of the world. Whether it's a natural process or a malevolent force, the Mimeoplasm never fails to command respect."

Like I said-- awesome flavor. Please make this set happen, Wizards!

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: Trygon_Predator
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed:
A fun card for Bear/vanilla/token creature decks.
Note that it does not ruin "strictly better", contrary to Toes_of_Krosa. The point of "strictly better", overused as it is on Gatherer, is that, in a vacuum, a card is better than another. Typhoid Rats, for instance, is strictly better than Muck Rats, because for the same amount of mana, you get a 1/1 deathtouch black rat instead of a plain 1/1 black rat. Adding Muraganda Petroglyphs, a enchantment, would make Muck Rats good, but it still wouldn't be "strictly better" than Typhoid Rats (and you could make the argument that a 1/1 deathtouch is still better than a 3/3 vanilla).
Just thought I'd get that out of the way. Too many comments on here are to the effect of "well, it is vanilla, but it's not strictly worse because Muraganda Petroglyphs!"
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_posted:

Note that it does [i]not[/i] ruin "strictly better", contrary to Toes_of_Krosa. The point of "strictly better", overused as it is on Gatherer, is that, in a vacuum, a card is better than another. [autocard]Typhoid Rats[/autocard], for instance, is strictly better than [autocard]Muck Rats[/autocard], because for the same amount of mana, you get a 1/1 deathtouch black rat instead of a plain 1/1 black rat. Adding Muraganda Petroglyphs, a [3][G] enchantment, would make Muck Rats good, but it still wouldn't be "strictly better" than Typhoid Rats (and you could make the argument that a 1/1 deathtouch is still better than a 3/3 vanilla).
Just thought I'd get that out of the way. Too many comments on here are to the effect of "well, it is vanilla, but it's not strictly worse because Muraganda Petroglyphs!"

130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.author: Toes_of_Krosa
130614: Muraganda Petroglyphs.text_parsed:
Ah Muraganda Petroglyphs, ruining the phrase "strictly better" since 2007.


Edit:
@Trygon_Predator:
I know full well the real definition of "strictly better", as stated by MaRo. I was simply making a joke based off the way it's misused so often. YOU, on the other hand, either gave a poor explanation or don't understand it yourself. The phrase "strictly better" means something like "better in the vast majority of common situations, to the point where the others are irrelevant." Thus, Muraganda Pertoglyphs would be irrelevant to whether Typhoid Rats is strictly better than Muck Rats (which it is, by the way).

130630: Thornweald Archer.author: ddde
130630: Thornweald Archer.text_parsed:
For something with reach and deathtouch is 1/2 better or worse then 2/1? While blocking, having that extra power won't help given the deathtouch and lack of first strike, but having the extra toughness could save your ass. When the creature pings power and toughness don't matter. On attack, greater power is better as you could kill multiple blockers or do extra damage to an opponent. Granted, the higher toughness can be better on attack if facing a small creature with first strike or if the opponent uses a very small blocker (1 power). Higher toughness is clearly better against any form of direct damage (such as being pinged).

On the whole I'd say that higher toughness is generally better for this type of creature. If you give it first strike or double strike that probably switches things to favor higher power. Note, however, that elves are a far better tribe then spiders.
130630: Thornweald Archer.text_posted:

130630: Thornweald Archer.author: Max_Glycine
130630: Thornweald Archer.text_parsed: I actually like this better than recluse, by a lot. The extra point of toughness only matters when your opponent is attacking with 1/1s, and if you're being attacked by 1/1s they're probably attacking with a lot of them, so a single creature matters less anyway. With this, you can apply a reasonable clock and pressure your opponent to block, in which case they'll eventually be forced to block, likely trading your two-drop with a bigger creature.

130635: Daybreak Coronet.author: Lazyblazey
130635: Daybreak Coronet.text_parsed:
Rancor's best friend. For three mana you get +5/+3, First Strike, Vigilance, Lifelink, and Trample. That's really impressive for a white/green deck, and even more so if they're on Kor Spiritdancer, Thran Golem, or Mistmeadow Skulk.

Its downside just encourages you to play more Auras to reduce its risk, and its mana cost narrows its usefulness only slightly. So if you have a white deck that already has a handful of Auras, including two or three copies of this will cause some major problems for your opponent. Well worth the slots in your deck.

130635: Daybreak Coronet.author: Haelthor
130635: Daybreak Coronet.text_parsed:
This is white's nail in the coffin as far as aura finishers. I give it 3.5 out of 5 because its a tricky deck to pull off, and you probably wouldn't want to run more than 2 (maybe 3) in a deck. Here's how you can justify its WW cost: it requires a early creature, hopefully with hexproof, followed by an aura (take your pick there are a LOT, from commons to rare to choose from). When you pull this, you've already spend around 3-5 mana for the dude and the aura, making this a 5WW mana investment enchantment, but you get to play it on turn 4 or 5 (as a finisher) PLUS you get to keep mana open for a counterspell or other shenanigans.

Think W/U
Slipery Bogle, Invisible Stalker, Geist of Saint Traft all fill the curve for hexproof super-beaters.
you have curiosity, spectral flight, traveler's cloak. And hell the shadowmoor common aura aren't half bad.
Follow that up with Daybreak Coronet and you've got probably a 2 turn clock on an opponent (with mana open for counter magiks).

Even if your guy dies, the lifelink should give you enough cushion to last to get on your feet again.
130635: Daybreak Coronet.text_posted:
This is white's nail in the coffin as far as aura finishers. I give it 3.5 out of 5 because its a tricky deck to pull off, and you probably wouldn't want to run more than 2 ([i]maybe[/i] 3) in a deck. Here's how you can justify its WW cost: it requires a early creature, hopefully with hexproof, followed by an aura (take your pick there are a LOT, from commons to rare to choose from). When you pull this, you've already spend around 3-5 mana for the dude and the aura, making this a 5WW mana investment enchantment, but you get to play it on turn 4 or 5 (as a finisher) PLUS you get to keep mana open for a counterspell or other shenanigans.

Think W/U 
Slipery Bogle, Invisible Stalker, Geist of Saint Traft all fill the curve for hexproof super-beaters.
you have curiosity, spectral flight, traveler's cloak. And  hell the shadowmoor common aura aren't half bad.
Follow that up with Daybreak Coronet and you've got probably a 2 turn clock on an opponent (with mana open for counter magiks).

Even if your guy dies, the lifelink should give you enough cushion to last to get on your feet again.

I realize it's quite efficient; but its playability seems marginal. It is likely in mono-white (in which case it's easier to 3-for-1) or it's possibly in a mixed color setting where the efficiency is more difficult to get at and the risk of being 2-for-1 or 3-for-1'd is still quite possible.

Further, against White, Green, or Blue, they can bounce/destroy one aura and kill this aura as well. While it'll pay off big time if it lands well, it's high-risk-high-reward behavior and I don't know if I buy into it on this instance.

130644: Virulent Sliver.author: blindcansee
130644: Virulent Sliver.text_parsed:
The poison does stack. You read it like it has two instances of poisonous 1.

This silver has poisonous 1 (add one counter)
This sliver has poisonous 1 (add one counter)

You read the first one and add the poison counter and then move the the second one. The only reason trample and vigilance are redundant is because if you applied the same rule it doesn't add anything. Take Lymph Sliver for example. Having two out would double the adsorb ability. That's how having two Plated Slivers gives all your slivers 0/+2 if you didn't apply the above rule the plus 0/+1 would be redundant.

All slivers get 0/+1
All slivers get 0/+1

130644: Virulent Sliver.text_posted:
The poison does stack. You read it like it has two instances of poisonous 1.

This silver has poisonous 1   (add one counter)
This sliver has poisonous 1   (add one counter)

You read the first one and add the poison counter and then move the the second one.  The only reason trample and vigilance are redundant is because if you applied the same rule it doesn't add anything. Take [autocard]Lymph Sliver[/autocard] for example. Having two out would double the adsorb ability.  That's how having two [autocard]Plated Sliver[/autocard]s gives all your slivers 0/+2 if you didn't apply the above rule  the plus 0/+1 would be redundant.

130659: Spellwild Ouphe.author: Mode
130659: Spellwild Ouphe.text_parsed:
I'd have liked it to reduce the cost of targeted abilities as well, but it still has some nice synergies (especially with auras and/or cantrips) nonetheless.

@A3Kitsune: Why would you want to finish by giving him shroud if you can start by giving him hexproof instead?
Shielding Plax only costs you one mana and will even net you a card.

Shield of the Oversoul, False Demise or Umbras (e.g. Boar Umbra or Bear Umbra) are a nice choice for that as well, but dependant on format that won't help you that much since the spot removal of choice will usually exile the creature.
If you run these though, Pariahmight be a nice choice if you're going to build a deck around this guy. (Further good creatures would then be Argothian Enchantress, Aura Gnarlid and maybe Auratog if you add Rancor or another recurring enchantment (that could be cast for one mana when the ouphe is targeted)).
You can also make it unblockable (actually even better) with Unquestioned Authority, which is a cantrip on top of that.
Angelic Destiny is also a great choice, i'd probably even play this over Gigantiform since it has Rancors trigger and also does a good job on your other creatures.

Flight of Fancy could be used for card advantage (and evasion).
Followed Footsteps is another great combo with this guy. Especially if you have a Pattern of Rebirth in hand, a way to kill the ouphe, and a fat creature in your library...sounds like too many conditions for that to work, but but on the other hand you don't need Followed Footsteps for that trick. But that one, or also cards like False Demise or Fool's Demise are pretty 'win more'-cards with it. (If you have a sac engine, you can also search for Iridescent Drake or Evershrike - which again is nice with Rancor as well.)

130672: Boldwyr Intimidator.author: Doghealer
130672: Boldwyr Intimidator.text_parsed:
When this gets reprinted, the containing set will:

-Introduce the "Coward" type, as an actual type on the type line, as opposed to just a type referenced by a text box and the Changeling keyword.

-Possibly introduce the overarching rule "Cowards can't block Warriors." or perhaps just "Cowards can't block.", kind of like how Walls couldn't attack back in the day.

-Otherwise, each creature with the Coward creature type will have an ability that says "As long as is a Coward, ". Some of these creatures may come with abilities that remove the Coward type from them under some condition. (Possible example: Lonely Fighter: 2/2 Human Coward, costs W, As long as Lonely Fighter is a Coward, it can't attack or block. As long as you control three or more creatures, Lonely Fighter loses the Coward type.)

-Include a permanent card (probably a creature) with "All creature you control lose the Coward creature type."

-Include a card at a cheap cost that temporarily removes the Coward creature type from target creature. Possibly on a stick of some sort.

-Include a sorcery card at a more expensive cost that permanently removes the Coward type from target creature (or possibly multiple creatures).


...On retrospect, this has already been reprinted.

.........Daaaaaaang. I tried.

130675: Storm Entity.author: Edward_Mass
130675: Storm Entity.text_parsed: I think people are missing the difference between "cast" and "copy". Copies are not cast, so they won't do anything for this guy. That's nothing to hold against the card, just pointing it out. As to the creature itself, it's kinda meh. Even in the format it was designed for, I'm not seeing a ton of value. The biggest mistake was probably giving it haste (as opposed to almost any other popular keyword). Fact is, if you're playing enough spells to get value out of this guy, haste isn't as relavent as, say, trample or shroud.

130676: Blade of the Sixth Pride.author: Zenzei
130676: Blade of the Sixth Pride.text_parsed:
I truly hope Magic has to never again suffer through crap like future sight, this card is one of the front runners of visually offending cards, not because the art itself is bad or something like that, but because this doesn't even remotely resemble a MtG card.

Same goes for all full art and foil stuff, it just looks hideous if your deck isn't of the same general card look. I wish wizards would at least print promotional cards non-foil because then you could actually play them in real tournaments and such (unlike foils, which can mark your deck unless you have 100% foil deck) and I do like alternate arts on many of these, unfortunately foil, promo cards.

130683: Ichor Slick.author: HairlessThoctar
130683: Ichor Slick.text_parsed:
The madness cost is higher because it needed to be.

1. Cycling can be activated at instant speed, ergo; the card can be madnessed at instant speed.
2. Madness is an ability, meaning it can't be countered by most counterspells.

6 for instant speed, can't be countered -3/-3 draw a card is totally worth it.
