136196: Dryad Arbor.author: Paleopaladin
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed: The last ruling on the card seems "wrong" -- why would it changing land types necessarily change the color?  Anyone explain that to me, please?
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_posted: The last ruling on the card seems "wrong" -- why would it changing land types necessarily change the color?  Anyone explain that to me, please?

136196: Dryad Arbor.author: Bowshewicz
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed: @Paleopaladin: That's because of how effects like "Enchanted land is an island" work. These effects cause the enchanted land to lose any abilities printed on the card, so Dryad Arbor would lose the static ability keeping it green.
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_posted: @Paleopaladin: That's because of how effects like "Enchanted land is an island" work. These effects cause the enchanted land to lose any abilities printed on the card, so Dryad Arbor would lose the static ability keeping it green.

136196: Dryad Arbor.author: Artscrafter
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed: @Paleopaladin: There's a rule that specifically handles the case where a land is set to a basic land type without an "in addition to its other types" clause, where this makes the land lose all of its other abilities. This includes the "Dryad arbor is green" ability. This doesn't affect a permanent's other card types, so this effect doesn't make Dryad Arbor stop being a creature.
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_posted: @Paleopaladin: There's a rule that specifically handles the case where a land is set to a basic land type without an "in addition to its other types" clause, where this makes the land lose all of its other abilities. This includes the "Dryad arbor is green" ability. This doesn't affect a permanent's other card types, so this effect doesn't make Dryad Arbor stop being a creature.

136196: Dryad Arbor.author: Kale_Eledar
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed:
It costs no mana.

It can't be countered.

It can be targeted by virtually any green or black fetch spell in the game. It has synergy with Life from the Loam, Fauna Shaman, Crucible of Worlds, Meloku, The Clouded Mirror etc, etc, etc.


It deserves a 5/5. Summoning sickness is a minor thing compared to the options this brings to the table. And are ya really gonna criticize a chump block against a Dark Confidant or Noble Hierarch? No. There's nothing strategically wrong with trading a 1/1 for a 1/1.

So it can be targeted by slightly more removal - but who's giving up slots in their decks for land destruction? Not very many builds these days. It's not like you're playing it for the desperate forest mana.

136196: Dryad Arbor.author: Sootoo
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed:
I love this card for its originality and its dryad flavor. Dryads are still some kind of 'underdogs' in this game, which makes this card only more interesting.

However, if it wasn´t for my Trostani deck and Green Sun's Zenith, I wouldn´t put it in any deck, since it´s just too vulnerable, especially in a multiplayer game like EDH, where almost every game occurs at least one creature board wipe.

To bring this out on turn one with Green Sun's Zenith is always awesome, though. Technically it´s something like a Rampant Growth for only 1 mana. It also comes great with cards like Gaea's Cradle, or Wayfaring Temple.

Still can`t understand why it doesn`t have forestwalk, though. Every dryad should have forestwalk, IMO, especially this one.

136196: Dryad Arbor.author: mdakw576
136196: Dryad Arbor.text_parsed:
This guy is great if used properly. Some examples...

- You can green sun's zenith this for X=0, giving you a llanowar elf basically.
- You can crack a forest fetchland to find this and surprise block. It's very satisfying to block a dark confidant with this.
- it can hold equipment.

There's enough value to run 1-2 in a typical deck, and it's worth consideration in an EDH deck. I've cracked a fetchland to find this in response to someone's fleshbag marauder, since I'd rather get stone rain'd then lose my Progenitus.

136199: Take Possession.author: DysprosiumJudas
136199: Take Possession.text_parsed:
Mind Control for 5 mana lets you have target creature.
Confiscate for 6 mana lets you have target permanent.
Take Possession for 7 mana lets you have target permanent and it can't be blocked.

To me, one of the most strategic decisions blue players have to make is which one of these three they want to run in a deck. All of them have their uses, and its really difficult to decide on one before you ever see an opponent's deck.

136199: Take Possession.author: Cyberium
136199: Take Possession.text_parsed:
Split Second is a good ability, but not as powerful as most think on this particular card.

Take Possession is an enchantment, so while it cannot be responded, once it's in play it can still be destroyed, and most sideboard packs enchantment destroyers.

Split Second means so much more on a sorcery or instant than on a permanent. Confiscate cost 1 less, and in most cases still get the job done.

136201: Imperial Mask.author: Dreznin
136201: Imperial Mask.text_parsed:
@MechaKraken - the reason it specifies "if it isn't a token" is because without that statement, this card would create an infinite loop in a team game. With this wording, the tokens that the mask spawns don't create more tokens.

Easy way to explain the infinite loop if it DIDN'T have that phrase:

You play the mask
When your mask comes into play, your ally gets a token
When your ally's mask comes into play, you get a token
When that token comes into play, your ally gets another
Etc.

As infinite loops with no way to end them are an automatic draw, the phrase excluding the tokens from creating tokens is what keeps this from being a game ending spell.
136201: Imperial Mask.text_posted:
@MechaKraken - the reason it specifies "if it isn't a token" is because without that statement, this card would create an infinite loop in a team game.   With this wording, the tokens that the mask spawns don't create more tokens.  

Easy way to explain the infinite loop if it DIDN'T have that phrase:

You play the mask
When your mask comes into play, your ally gets a token
When your ally's mask comes into play, you get a token
When that token comes into play, your ally gets another
Etc.

As infinite loops with no way to end them are an automatic draw, the phrase excluding the tokens from creating tokens is what keeps this from being a game ending spell.

136204: Aven Mindcensor.author: Titanium_Dragon
136204: Aven Mindcensor.text_parsed: This card is far stronger than it looks; it is basically a situational counterspell which can also act like a Stifle on fetchlands, potentially effectively dropping a flying Avalanche Riders on them. It can completely mess up a deck which relies heavily on tutoring, but it is very vulnerable to removal and not all that good unless your opponent plays tutors; as such, it is doomed to see play mostly as a means to mess up those who play fetchlands. May be much more of a contender in extended once Mirrodin rotates out and EVERY deck ends up playing fetchland manabases.

136204: Aven Mindcensor.author: Ogonomany
136204: Aven Mindcensor.text_parsed:
I think that the best part of this card is how bad it can make your opponent feel. They crack a fetch and you Stifle it or play Shadow of Doubt, they just accept that you got them and they lose a land. You play this, there is still the hope that the card they need is there on top of the library, and then when it's not, it makes them feel so bad. And then they have to still shuffle, just to rub it in their faces.

Powerful effect on an evasive creature with decent stats. 5/5 for me.

136205: Street Wraith.author: Azazyel
136205: Street Wraith.text_parsed:
Great cycling - I'd pay 2 life over 2 mana any day. The problem is, the card it's attached to just isn't that good: a 3/4 for five mana with very conditional evasion. For a cycling card to be really playable, it has to either be attached to something that the player would consider playing normally (see Decree of Silence, Angelsong, hell, even Vedalken Aethermage), or the cycling has to hold an additional benefit besides simply putting a card in your hand (the landcycling spells from Alara, definitely Vedalken Aethermage, etc.).

If you can't contemplate playing a creature with cycling normally, and I know I wouldn't with Street Wraith (even in the most casual of decks, black has a lot better things to be doing at five mana), then all you get is a card that draws you a single other card - that is to say, a waste of a card slot.


Of course, this is not accounting for cycling-based decks, where this card could actually work, and work splendidly. Proof of concept that every card in Magic is playable, if you can find a home for it.

136205: Street Wraith.author: PeabodyET
136205: Street Wraith.text_parsed:
A cycling card doesnt necessarily have to be playable on its own if the cycling effect is free. Basically, this card gives you three things:
1) A black creature card in your graveyard. This is useful in reanimator strategies, obviously. But it also give you advantages for cards like Stitched Drake, Splinterfright, Ichorid, and Avatar of Woe.
2) A replacement card. This is not, as was said, a waste of a card slot. This lets you essentially pay life to run a 56 card deck. If your goal is to get to a specific card for your combo, youre more likely to get there if you have fewer cards in your deck.
3) No tempo loss. Normally, if you cycle a card, play a search effect like Sleight of Hand or Faithless Looting, or similar, you use mana to do it, and thus use an early turn. Street Wraith cycles with no tempo loss. He can also be cycled at instant speed, which makes it better than Gitaxian Probe. And because it is cycling and doesn't target anything, it's much harder for your opponent to stop it.

This card could be a 9 mana 0/1 that comes into play tapped and it wouldnt change how you play it. You run this card for the free cycling. The 3/3 body makes it better in reanimation strategies, but youre never putting this in your deck to be a 5-mana 3/3.

136206: Nihilith.author: night8883
136206: Nihilith.text_parsed:
It slithered into this world through the cracks in my mind. Only when my sanity was completely shattered did it fully reveal itself to me.

I just ordered a foil version of this card for my Vela EDH deck which has lots of discard and evasion. Horrors are my favorite creature type, and this is one of my favorites. The colors are awesome, and I love how only a portion of the Nihilith is visible; the silhouette is mysterious and disturbing, the fact that most of the horror is hidden makes it especially scary. In EDH games this thing slithers out really quickly, and comes in with haste off of suspend. In the games I've played people are afraid of it. Very cheap set it and forget it efficient creature.

136206: Nihilith.author: blurrymadness
136206: Nihilith.text_parsed:
Death cloud is an ok way to play this guy. Kill spells next to Wight of Precinct Six is an ok way to go. Discard cards can cause him to come out as early as T3 or 4. (Opponent attacks, you and him trade creatures (say a fume spitter), suspend takes off 1 counter, opponent plays 2 spells, you cause discard 3 with Delirium Skeins, not probable, but quite possible.)

4/4 Fear is quite powerful, and discard means your opponent probably is missing the removal he needs to answer it. This guy is a serious consideration with a mix of removal, discard, and things like Burning Inquiry.


Also? Way way better in multiplayer. You get a 4/4 for 2, probably attacking T3, with haste. Having trouble getting it out? Smallpox

136206: Nihilith.text_parsed:
I have to disagree on those saying that you wouldn't want this on a mill deck.

That statement is true if your goal is to mill out your opponent to achieve victory. But you can build a mill deck where milling is only a means to an end. With cards like Jace's Phantasm, Wight of Precinct Six, Consuming Aberration, etc. it's actually a pretty good beatdown deck with mill as a ressource generator (rather than a goal in itself).

136207: Dust of Moments.author: xTamx420
136207: Dust of Moments.text_parsed:
What about exiling cards with suspend and then using this?

For example use Selective memory to exile a bunch of cards with suspend (Corpulent Corpse for example) then use this to put two time counters on them all and you get them two upkeeps later. Do these exiled cards count as being suspended?
136207: Dust of Moments.text_posted:
What about exiling cards with suspend and then using this?

For example use Selective memory to exile a bunch of cards with suspend (Corpulent Corpse for example) then use this to put two time counters on them all and you get them two upkeeps later. Do these exiled cards count as being suspended?

136207: Dust of Moments.author: Guest513736147
136207: Dust of Moments.text_parsed:
I got incredibly excited when you mentioned that, xTamx420. Unfortunately, I think a "suspended card" is defined as a card that:

a) has suspend
b) has time counters on it
c) is in the exile zone

So unfortunately those cards would not meet criterion b), since when you exile them they would not have any time counters on them. So they would not technically be suspended cards and, thus, no added time counters.

I was really disappointed when I started researching that, because the ability to have 4 Greater Gargadons, 4 Deep Sea Krakens, and 4 Ancestral Visions happen in 2 turns because of two under appreciated cards (this and Selective Memory) sounded utterly amazing to me. Alas.
136207: Dust of Moments.text_posted:
I got incredibly excited when you mentioned that, xTamx420. Unfortunately, I think a "suspended card" is defined as a card that:

b) has time counters on it

So unfortunately those cards would not meet criterion b), since when you exile them they would not have any time counters on them. So they would not technically be suspended cards and, thus, no added time counters.

I was really disappointed when I started researching that, because the ability to have 4 [autocard]Greater Gargadon[/autocard]s, 4 [autocard]Deep Sea Kraken[/autocard]s, and 4 [autocard]Ancestral Vision[/autocard]s happen in 2 turns because of two under appreciated cards (this and [autocard]Selective Memory[/autocard]) sounded utterly amazing to me. Alas.

136207: Dust of Moments.author: Juicebox360
136207: Dust of Moments.text_parsed:
@xTamx420: Looks like the comprehensive rules say no. :<

702.60b A card is "suspended" if it's in the exile zone, has suspend, and has a time counter on it.
136207: Dust of Moments.text_posted:
@xTamx420: Looks like the comprehensive rules say no. :<

[b]702.60b A card is "suspended" if it's in the exile zone, has suspend, and has a time counter on it.[/b]

136207: Dust of Moments.author: NARFNra
136207: Dust of Moments.text_parsed:
This is, of course, a heavily limited card, but it's sure not worse than Cyclical Evolution. It feels like a neat trick to me, if you can get multiple cards to hit 2 Time Counters, Dust of Moments will actually let you cast them all without warning, instantly.

"When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost."

Which feels like it would be a possibly nice thing to do with something like Phthisis, a card that suffers from being a removal spell without the surprise.

136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.author: Chamale
136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.text_parsed:
His Grandeur ability gives me an idea for a mono-black Madness deck that partially revolves around Korlash.

Grandeur is discard, not exile, so my idea includes these cards:

Call to the Netherworld
Death Denied,
Macabre Waltz
Grave Scrabbler

After you've used Korlash's Grandeur once or twice, it's time to use Disturbed Burial. You'll have enough swamps keep putting Korlash back into your hand.

136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.author: DrakenDark
136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.text_parsed:
I disagree with the comments saying that is is a better version of nightmare.

sure nightmare cost 2 more to play... but that made it a 6/6 flyer in mono black. Korlash, even with grandeur, is just a 6/6, it can be chump blocked all day, it doesn't have trample. if it had trample it would be another story. so repeat grandeur as many times as you want... it still would be chumped by any blocker, and especially if that blocker had regen.

not saying its a bad card, i just think nightmare is a notch above it.

it does awesome things for legendary creatures, gives a purpose to having multiple copies, and it does do a lovely job with mana acceleration.

136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.author: DoragonShinzui
136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.text_parsed:
Oh Korlash, how I love thee. Let me count the ways:
1. You are a Zombie. Zombies are such a fun tribe.
2. You hare both strong and durable. No cheap deaths for you, even if you can be chumped.
3. Other copies of you have a unique purpose: Black mana ramp. And with the right cards, especially Call to the Netherworld, you make for an incredible platform for accelerating that which black has little for.
4. You just overall look badass, and you manage to make the Future Shifted frame look outrageously classy and badass.

136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.author: Dakkon_BlackBlade_LG
136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.text_parsed:
As astounding as it sounds, he's my Favorite General. I love the Art, he's one of the few "Heroic" Type warrior Legendary card that Magic as that can get behind, the other one was Dakkon Blackblade.
My friend told me he's an awful general or something like that. And objectively he's not the leader type that is going to boost your team or your deck. His grandeur ability is even useless in Commander.

As a commander he as a low profile and is often dismissed by other players before the game start and he also force you to play black only and artifacts.

My deck as lots of massive creature destruction spells and artifacts, some of which Korlash can regenerate from and live.

I try to deplete my opponents Hand, wipe the board when I can.

And then I send him in. After blowing a board, Kresh comes back as a 3/3, but often Korlash is ready to go as a 10/10 or more.

And you can send Korlash in the Red zone relentlessly knowing he will most likely take something down and survive.

And he's cheap to recast, with cabal coffer around he can keep coming back for a long time.

136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.author: blurrymadness
136208: Korlash, Heir to Blackblade.text_parsed:
Very good with infernal tutor. 6 total mana = Korlash + 2 rampant growths, can make your t2 tutor a ridiculous t4 play

Also, Tortured existence turns every creature in your hand into a "{B}: Entwined Journey of Discovery", especially with ravnica shock lands.

Also, you can granduer off of reanimation mind you; so he's the easiest to granduer between that and black's Rituals and black's extensive tutoring. Imagine an Exhume, Shallow Grave, or similar on T2, for 2 cards you ramp two swamps. Next turn if you simply Ghoulcaller's you can get them both back, cast one of them, then granduer the other again!

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: KarmasPayment
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed:
Simply astounding, a counter or bounce that gives a 2/2 upon resolution.

I do wish he was more like Voidmage Husher in one of two ways though, by either being able to counter an activated ability, or by having some sort of re-usability outside of the Erratic Portal/Crystal Shard/Equilibrium-esque cards. Reusable bounce might have made him too good though.

Maybe if he had something along the likes of Sakashima the Impostor's : Return Venser to owners hand at the end of turn, it would have been alright without being too broken or re-abuseable.

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: Ladon---
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed:
@ChampionofSquee

He can "counter" Emrakul, the Aeons Torn, but since your opponent just cast Emrakul he'll still get an extra turn... and there's a good chance Emrakul is coming out on that turn, landing him another extra turn... which means Venser isn't much use against him.

If you're looking to counter Emrakul and other uncounterables, I think you need look no further than Mindbreak Trap.

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: hunter90000
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed: @guitarman71084: Yes, the spell Emrakul could be returned to your hand by this, Emrakul only has protection from colored spells when it's a permanent, not as a spell. Since returning a spell to your hand is different than countering, it would get around Emrakul's uncounterable ability too. See Emrakul's rulings about protection.
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_posted: @guitarman71084: Yes, the spell Emrakul could be returned to your hand by this, Emrakul only has protection from colored spells when it's a permanent, not as a spell. Since returning a spell to your hand is different than countering, it would get around Emrakul's uncounterable ability too. See Emrakul's rulings about protection.

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: adrian.malacoda
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed:
The permanent Emrakul can also be targeted by this. When Venser ETB he is a permanent, not a spell. Emrakul won't have protection from it. The same applies to emrakul's interaction with oblivion ring, see http://community.wizards.com/go/thread/view/75842/28910957/?pg=last

@Totema

That only applies to "future shifted" cards with the special "future" border (i.e. Tarmogoyf).

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: GrimjawxRULES
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed:
Works well with the planeswalker: when creature-Venser is on the battlefield, bounce him with 'walker-Venser. Then when creature-Venser enters the battlefield again, bounce him to your hand with his own ability, and bam! recurrable "counterspell". You could even take the time to Wrath the board while creature-Venser is in exile if you want.
Also worth noting that he abuses etb and cast triggers for .

136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.author: Three_Toe
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_parsed: This guy is a great general for mono blue control EDH. The fact that he's a creature means there are a lot of ways to bounce him back to your hand or get multiple bounces with him, including riptide laboratory, crystal shard, erratic portal, deadeye navigator, sunken hope, mimic vat words of wind, equilibrium, evacuation (drawback becomes benefit, opponents get hosed), cryptic command, kederekt leviathan, veldaken mastermind, peel from reality etc.. I had never played him before I made an EDH for him, and I didn't think he would be that useful, but once you experience what he can do, you realize why blue control players love him.
136209: Venser, Shaper Savant.text_posted: This guy is a great general for mono blue control EDH. 136210: Oriss, Samite Guardian.author: reapersaurus
136210: Oriss, Samite Guardian.text_parsed:
This card, and its (non)reaction to on here, is a testament to how absurdly over-powered Magic has become.

Oriss is the ultimate evolution of Samite Healer (from Alpha days) and the various healers they have put out over the decade(s) - except instead of preventing SOME damage, they just said "screw it - lets let her prevent ALL the damage to a creature. Let's make her a Legend, but let's give her Grandeur so extras aren't wasted" (probably the most elegant/useful rule for the inclusion of Legends they could have ever come up with), and people STILL won't even think of playing with a healer, because they have boosted the power level of creatures SO much. ROFL

ROFL

136213: Patrician's Scorn.author: ScissorsLizard
136213: Patrician's Scorn.text_parsed:
Pretty powerful; I'd even call it underrated. In a mono white deck, you'll always be playing white spells, so you will frequently be given opportunities to use this for free. And if you don't have any spells, well then you can always hard cast it, especially since you don't have a better play.

If you can get 2 enchantments with this one card, especially if you can screw up combat with it, you've just won card advantage, decimated the field, and you didn't even have to pay any extra mana.

The downside, of course, is that it will hit your own enchantments, so don't put it in a deck that uses a lot of them.

136214: Shapeshifter's Marrow.author: Fictionarious
136214: Shapeshifter's Marrow.text_parsed:
QUESTION:
Shapeshifter's Marrow specifies on the card and in the rulings that it (Shapeshifter's Marrow, referring to the card itself not just the creature/enchantment it might be at any given time) becomes a copy of the creature revealed on your opponent's library. If I then return it to my hand with Vedalken Mastermind, will I return a copy of my opponent's creature card to my hand, right down to the mana cost, ready to be played again? Or will it go back to being an enchantment in my hand again?
136214: Shapeshifter's Marrow.text_posted:

136214: Shapeshifter's Marrow.author: Salient
136214: Shapeshifter's Marrow.text_parsed:
@lorendorky - I guess the one good thing about having Chippy draw art for crap cards is that I can afford to have all the cards with Chippy's art...

And I agree Chippy's one of the best. Notice how this is tailor-made to look awesome in the "future style" art format? It would actually look weirdly diagonalized in a standard rectangle. Bridge From Below and Tarmogoyf (both great cards) looks like crap in the future sight border; this drake-copier looks amazing.

Though, is it really a crap card? Using Jace TMS to fateseal the opponent every turn, you would have greater control over which creature Marrow becomes. I guess the question's really whether a Jace-combo card is really worth it given that you already spent on Jace.

136215: Emblem of the Warmind.author: KyleJEdwards
136215: Emblem of the Warmind.text_parsed: You should note that the card enchants "creature you control." If an aura is ever enchanting something that dosn't meet it's requirements, then it will go to the graveyard as a state based action. So if you ever manage to control someone else's creature (You play Threaten on their creature and then enchant it with Emblem of the Warmind and it goes back at the end of the turn) or if the permanent it is enchanting is no longer a creature (You activate a Mutavault, then enchant it with Emblem of the Warmind and it becomes only a land at the end of the turn) then the enchantment will go to its owner's graveyard.
136215: Emblem of the Warmind.text_posted: You should note that the card enchants "creature [b]you[/b] control." If an aura is ever enchanting something that dosn't meet it's requirements, then it will go to the graveyard as a state based action. So if you ever manage to control someone else's creature (You play [autocard]Threaten[/autocard] on their creature and then enchant it with [autocard]Emblem of the Warmind[/autocard] and it goes back at the end of the turn) or if the permanent it is enchanting is no longer a creature (You activate a [autocard]Mutavault[/autocard], then enchant it with [autocard]Emblem of the Warmind[/autocard] and it becomes only a land at the end of the turn) then the enchantment will go to its owner's graveyard.

136215: Emblem of the Warmind.author: Mike-C
136215: Emblem of the Warmind.text_parsed: Compare to Fires of yavimaya. I like both and neither is strictly better or worse than the other. One is cheaper which is a huge plus for haste as in the earlier you play it, the better. While the other gives you an added +2/+2 bonus that has almost always helped me when I played fires but it has a drawback of costing 1 additional . The drawback here is, it's much more suseptible to removal as its tied to a creature. Plus, if you lose it, you most likely lost a creature too (not a very good one if you were smart) but still, getting two for oned is never fun. All in all I like it, and IMO its strictly better than Fervor, which is probably the one closest in category to compare with, but many could and prob will make the removal argument and I totally get why they'd pay 1 more mana to make it harder to get rid of..

136216: Pyromancer's Swath.author: statiefreez
136216: Pyromancer's Swath.text_parsed:
@reapersaurus

I love how so many comments on here are completely ignoring the fact that IF YOUR OPPONENT IS DEAD, you win.

This is kind of a problem for your opponent.

Losing when at 0 life is not something you can exactly recover from in Magic...

Now, if this card said, "play this when you have a ton of mana or after casting a bunch of rituals. Shock your opponent every time you cast a burn spell, and when you go into topdeck mode, your burn spells still Shock your opponent." Actually, it kind of says that already.

On a more serious note, since when has the red mage had trouble with dealing 21 damage with 13 cards (by t6)? Almost never, if you know what you're doing.
A few useful spells to accompany this:
Violent Eruption: Bonus points for hitting your own Mogg Maniac.
Fiery Temper
Shivan Meteor
Rift Bolt
Arc Blade
Conflagrate (flashbacked to discard your hand)
Devil's Play
Firebolt
Fires of Undeath
Geistflame
Lava Dart
Lightning Surge
Increasing Vengeance and any of your burn
Grapeshot
Past in Flames and a lot of rituals and burn (ie, your average Storm deck)
Volley of Boulders
Cackling Flames

For extra shenanigans, play this with Furnace of Rath on the board. People die very quickly.

Also, Dropping this with Recycle on board generally means that your burn spells suddenly replace themselves (just be sure to have Flashback cards in your graveyard to start drawing again).

136216: Pyromancer's Swath.author: fibonacci112358
136216: Pyromancer's Swath.text_parsed:
Now unplayable thanks to Guttersnipe.

I don't normally use "strictly better" or "strictly worse" when describing cards of two different types... but I am very tempted here.

===

EDIT:

@El_Pared

I'm very glad you made that reply because it's certainly true that Pyromancer's Swath triggers off each ping... however, if you had Guttersnipe on the board while you were building up your storm count, you still get +2 damage from each ping (it just happens BEFORE you cast your grapeshot).

Having said this, Swath gives you:
1) the option of putting it on the table only immediately before casting grapeshot, and
2) it contributes +2 damage from storm counts that come from casting creatures/enchantments/artifacts (whereas Guttersnipe only yields +2 damage off instants and sorceries) - but then again... how many permanents are you going to play in your storm deck??

With these two advantages in mind (mainly just the first one), I have to say the second paragraph on Swath still makes it a little worse than Guttersnipe.

===

Second edit:

And lets not forget that Guttersnipe lets you STORM THEM OUT without even finding a single card with "storm" written on it!!

For swath to work, you need to build your storm count, find and resolve your swath AND then find and resolve your grapeshot. For guttersnipe to work, you need to find and resolve your guttersnipe, and then build a storm count (finding a grapeshot is just gravy here).
